SOC100.name: Introduction to Sociology
SOC100.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC100.description: Nature of sociological inquiry. Concepts and principles of sociology. Institutional features of modern society. Structure and dynamics of social organizations.

SOC131.name: Social Problems
SOC131.description: The role of social movements, the legal system, public policy and opinion in the resolution of poverty, crime, racism, sexism, and ecological problems.

SOC161.name: International Development and Change
SOC161.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC161.description: Global issues of development and change. Population growth, poverty, structural inequalities, environmental degradation, social conflicts, social movements. Alternative development strategies and future perspectives.

SOC214.name: Social Inequality
SOC214.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC214.description: Theories of structural social inequality. Formation and change of inequalities among social classes and class structures, gender, and race. Inequalities and their interactions in modern societies. Consequences of inequalities. Current inequality trends.

SOC215.name: Race and Ethnicity
SOC215.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC215.description: Racial and ethnic problems in contemporary society. Prejudice, discrimination, conflict, and racial and ethnic identity and segregation in western and non-western societies.

SOC216.name: Sex, Gender, and Sexuality
SOC216.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC216.description: Social structural and social psychological perspectives on gender identity, sex category, and sexuality. Issues related to gender identity and sexuality in selected societal institutions and across cultures.

SOC220.name: Criminology
SOC220.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC220.description: Introduction to the socio-legal foundation of crime. Crime typology and measurement procedures. Theory and public policy. Societal responses to crime and criminals.
SOC220.restrictions: Open to students in the Peace and Justice Studies Minor or in the Sociology Major or in the Youth and Society Minor or in the Criminal Justice Major or in the Law, Justice, and Public Policy Minor or in the Conservation and Environmental Law Enforcement Minor or approval of school.

SOC241.name: Social Psychology
SOC241.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC241.description: Relationship of individuals to their social environment. Social influences on personality, attitudes and behavior.

SOC252.name: Introduction to Environmental Sociology
SOC252.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC252.description: Key concepts, theories, methods, and findings in environmental sociology.

SOC281.name: Social Research Methods
SOC281.description: Design and execution of social research. Ethics in research. Conceptualization, measurement, sampling, data collection, validity and reliability. Descriptive analysis. Presentation of conclusions.

SOC282.name: Quantitative Analysis for Social Research
SOC282.description: Experiments. Selected quantitative techniques of data analysis including regression and analysis of variance.

SOC310.name: Global Migration
SOC310.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC310.description: Theory and research on the causes and consequences of human migration. Sociological, social psychological, historical, and demographic perspectives.

SOC315.name: Family and Society
SOC315.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC315.description: Family development. Diversity of family form and organization in relation to personality, class, race, and gender.

SOC316.name: Youth and Society
SOC316.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC316.description: Behavioral analysis of youth. Youth subcultures. Youth at risk. Social change and youth behavior.

SOC319.name: Introduction to Earth System Science
SOC319.description: Systems approach to Earth as an integration of geochemical, geophysical, biological and social components. Global dynamics at a variety of spatio-temporal scales. Sustainability of the Earth system.

SOC322.name: Sociology of Work
SOC322.description: Social significance of work. Forces changing contemporary occupational structure. Career patterns. Occupational status and mobility. Social organization of various types of work. Gender and work. Social influence on work attitudes.

SOC325.name: Play, Games, and Sports
SOC325.description: How we learn about ourselves through playing, games, and participating in sports. Game development, and rule development and implementation in games and sports. Role of the media in determining appropriate behavior.

SOC331.name: Political Sociology
SOC331.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC331.description: Social power theories, dynamics, and structures. The economy and the polity. Power elites and democracy. Social bases of political behavior and participation. Sociopolitical movements.

SOC350.name: Society and Mental Health
SOC350.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC350.description: Social determinants of mental health and mental illness. International and cross-cultural comparison of mental health and mental illness.
SOC350.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

SOC351.name: Gendered Violence and Intersections of Power (Interim Change)
SOC351.description: Gendered violence from an intersectional perspective. Ways intersecting social statuses such as race, class, and sexuality shape gendered experiences.

SOC360.name: Migration and Social Change (Interim New)
SOC360.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC360.description: Survey of contemporary theory and research on migration and social change.
SOC360.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

SOC361.name: Contemporary Communities
SOC361.description: Approaches to the study of contemporary communities. Differential levels of community complexity. Social problems and dynamics of community change and development in local settings and their relation to external institutions.

SOC362.name: Developing Societies
SOC362.description: Dynamics of agricultural and industrial transformations in developing nations. Structural problems, behavioral patterns, and institutional changes at local and societal levels. Socioeconomic interdependencies in the world system.

SOC363.name: Rural Sociology
SOC363.description: Overview of rural societies in transition. Adjustments of rural people, families, and communities to societal changes. Survival strategies. Social aspects of contemporary agriculture and rural development processes.

SOC368.name: Science, Technology, and Society
SOC368.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC368.description: Role of science and technology in social change. Values and ethics in contemporary perspectives, controversies, and cases. Science and technology as forms of knowledge.
SOC368.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

SOC375.name: Urban Sociology
SOC375.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC375.description: Social theories and research on urban development, organization, and change. Urban social life. Sociological aspects of urban planning and redevelopment.

SOC412.name: Animals, People, and Nature
SOC412.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC412.description: Sociological overview of the intersecting roles of animals, culture, and nature in contemporary society.

SOC416.name: Global Regions
SOC416.description: Overview of a specified global region within a context of global transformations.

SOC424.name: Organizations and Society
SOC424.description: Formal and informal organizations and bureaucracies. Interorganizational relationships. Structural and procedural problems of organizations. Utility of analytical models of organizations.
SOC424.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

SOC427.name: Environmental Toxicology and Society
SOC427.description: Impact of environmental chemicals on health and modern society. Cellular and organ functions and their interface with the environment. Limitations of scientific investigation and environmental regulations.

SOC447.name: Community Economic Development
SOC447.description: Theories, frameworks, policies, concepts, principles, models, and skills for community economic development. Community participation in local development initiatives.

SOC451.name: Dynamics of Population
SOC451.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC451.description: Size, distribution, and composition of population by age and sex. Theories of the effect of fertility, mortality, and migration on population structures. Successful and unsuccessful population policies.

SOC452.name: Advanced Seminar in Environmental Sociology
SOC452.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC452.description: Environmental conditions and social organization. Social relations and connection to resource use, pollution, energy, and risks. Growth and limits to growth. Environmental attitudes, actions, movements, and regulation.

SOC463.name: Food Fight: Politics of Food
SOC463.description: Social power and its influence in US agrifood system. Structural and cultural issues related to politics of food consumption, production, labor, processing, retail, techno-science, policy, resistance movements.
SOC463.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

SOC475.name: Health and Society
SOC475.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC475.description: Social causes of Health and disease. Health disparities related to race-ethnicity, socioeconomic status, gender and family. Organizations, professions and institutions of health care. Medical standards and evidence. Global public health.
SOC475.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

SOC477.name: Visual Sociology
SOC477.description: Use of visual images to understand power, ideology, politics, and cultural constructions.

SOC478.name: Climate Change and Society
SOC478.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC478.description: Climate change as a societal challenge. The nature of climate change, its role in human history, and vulnerabilities of coupled human and natural systems to climate change.
SOC478.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

SOC480.name: Advanced Research Methods in Sociology
SOC480.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC480.description: Advanced training and hands-on practice in methodologies commonly used in specific sub-fields of sociology.
SOC480.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors.

SOC481.name: Social Movements and Collective Identities
SOC481.description: How social movements emerge, change, and are challenged by others. Identity issues within social movements.

SOC488.name: Sociological Theory (W)
SOC488.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC488.description: Development of sociological theory. Problems of theory construction. Current theoretical perspectives.
SOC488.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

SOC490.name: Special Topics in Sociology
SOC490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC490.description: Experimental courses and courses taught by visiting scholars.
SOC490.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Sociology.

SOC496.name: Individual Readings
SOC496.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC496.description: Supervised individual readings and study in sociology.

SOC497.name: Individual Research
SOC497.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

SOC498.name: Sociology Internship
SOC498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
SOC498.description: Practical experience with a public, private, or nonprofit organization.

SOC499.name: Social Issues and Change in Contemporary Society (W)
SOC499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
SOC499.description: Selected major social problems in contemporary societies. Sources and consequences of social change. Application of sociological theory to selected cases.
SOC499.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

SOC801.name: Global Transformations
SOC801.description: The impact of political, economic, and cultural globalization on states, cities, and local communities.

SOC815.name: Classical Sociological Theory
SOC815.description: Nineteenth- and early twentieth-century sociological theory from Marx to Pareto in socio-historical context. Development of contemporary sociology theory and research from the classics.

SOC816.name: Contemporary Sociological Theory
SOC816.description: Theories and conceptual schemes of contemporary social theorists. Relevance for sociological research.

SOC820.name: Contemporary Sociological Research in the Family
SOC820.description: Family structure. Family and marital attitudes. Family and social policy.

SOC833.name: Gender and Power
SOC833.description: Theory and research on gender and sexual inequality in socially-based systems of production and reproduction. Global and national gender inequalities in selected institutional settings.

SOC836.name: Race, Politics, and Social Structure
SOC836.description: National and international perspectives on the structures and manifestations of racial inequality. Concepts, methods, and quantitative and qualitative analysis.

SOC839.name: Structural Inequalities and Families
SOC839.description: Macrostructural forces and family life. Role of class, race, and gender.

SOC840.name: Animals and Social Transformations
SOC840.description: Historical examination of the human-animal relationships.

SOC852.name: Migration and Social Change
SOC852.semester: Fall of odd years, Spring of even years
SOC852.description: Theory and research on the causes and consequences of human migration. Sociological, social psychological, and demographic perspectives.

SOC858.name: Gender, Justice and Environmental Change : Issues and Concepts
SOC858.description: Issues and concepts related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Key debates and theoretical approaches to addressing environmental issues from a gender and social justice perspective. Gender and environment issues and processes from a global perspective.

SOC859.name: Gender, Justice, and Environmental Change: Methods and Application
SOC859.description: Methods and case studies related to gender, ecology, and environmental studies. Methodological and fieldwork issues from a feminist perspective in international and intercultural contexts. Qualitative and quantitative methods for integrating social and environmental data.

SOC865.name: Environmental Sociology
SOC865.description: Effects of attitudes, social structure, and policy on the causes and consequences of natural resource depletion, pollution, energy use, growth, and technological risks. Response of movements and policies to environmental problems.

SOC869.name: Community and Conservation
SOC869.semester: Fall of even years, Summer of even years
SOC869.description: Use of experiential, participatory, field-based mode of inquiry to develop understanding of social and cultural issues associated with conservation. Understanding of different social positions and perspectives.

SOC873.name: Social Organization of Health and Medicine
SOC873.description: Organization, delivery, and financing of health care. Public health systems, professional training and associations, and technology. International comparisons.

SOC881.name: Analysis of Social Data I
SOC881.description: Applications of statistical techniques to social science data. Multiple regression. SPSS. Interpretation, strengths, and weaknesses of various statistical practices.
SOC881.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Sociology.

SOC882.name: Analysis of Social Data II
SOC882.description: Applications of multiple regression, path analysis, and factor analysis to social science data. Interpretation, strengths, and weaknesses of commonly used statistical practices.
SOC882.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Sociology.

SOC883.name: Multi-Equation Quantitative Models
SOC883.prerequisite: SOC 881 and SOC 882 or approval of department
SOC883.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Sociology and open to graduate students in the Environmental Science and Policy Specialization or approval of department.

SOC884.name: Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
SOC884.description: Application of statistical methods to analyze data in a longitudinal design.

SOC885.name: Methods of Sociological Inquiry
SOC885.description: Methods of social science. Comparison of methods. Philosophy of science and social science. Epistemology.
SOC885.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Sociology major or approval of department.

SOC890.name: Individual Readings
SOC890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

SOC897.name: Seminar in Feminist Theories, Epistemologies, and Pedagogy
SOC897.description: Foundational knowledge, theory, epistemology, and pedagogy in women’s and gender studies from a multi-disciplinary, global perspective.

SOC899.name: Master's Thesis Research
SOC899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

SOC931.name: Topics in Structural Inequality
SOC931.description: Current research on socioeconomic class, gender inequality, racial and ethnic inequality, power structures, social conflict, urban dynamics, or social change.

SOC950.name: Topics in Rural and Environmental Studies
SOC950.description: Adoption of innovations, consolidation of food production enterprises, or community response to farm crises.

SOC970.name: Topics in Wellbeing and Health
SOC970.description: Topics such as family work and stress, risk and uncertainty, social epidemiology, and life course.

SOC977.name: Social Epidemiology
SOC977.description: Introduction to the field of social epidemiology and the social determinants of health. Contemporary theoretical and methodological issues in social epidemiology.
SOC977.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Epidemiology and Biostatistics or approval of department.

SOC985.name: Qualitative Field Research
SOC985.description: Qualitative research methods. Participant observation, interview, and field documents. Design, data gathering, and analysis.
SOC985.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in Sociology.

SOC986.name: Survey Research Principles
SOC986.description: Design, analysis, sampling, questionnaire construction, interviewing, and data processing.

SOC989.name: Topics in Sociological Methodology
SOC989.description: Evaluation research. Experimental or comparative research methods.

SOC995.name: Professional Training Seminar
SOC995.description: Development of knowledge and skills for the profession of sociology. Course design, teaching techniques, acquiring grants, outreach activities, collaboration with community and government, publishing and networking. Preparation of course syllabi, teaching philosophy, research agenda and job application.
SOC995.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Sociology.

SOC999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
SOC999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
